EPHEMERON. In the sphere of vast existenceâ Its beginning and its goal Lost in dim unmeasured distanceâ Dwells the solitary Soul. Longing for the light eternal, Through the gloom its footsteps bend. Though a gleam of Day Supernal On its darkness may descendâ Clouds terrestrial, shades infernal, Close around it to the end. Long ago 'twas said by Homer, Men are like the race of leavesâ Can Geneva or Saint Omer More assure a soul that grieves (Still from faith to doubt a roamer) O'er the little it receives? For there is but one thing certain, That the Earth will have her dueâ Bony fingers draw the curtain When the farce is fairly through. That the fount of life is flying Through our pulses, wave on waveâ And we are but slowly dying From the cradle to the grave. Human Love, and Tears, and Laughter, Haunt these fated dwellings nowâ Inconceivable Hereafter! What companionship hast thou? Dreary Riddle!âwho, by taking Thought, shall read thee?âmay we deem Life the sleep, and death the waking From a long distempered dream? Or, forlorn of its Ideal, Must the heart, in self-defence, Turn, for something that is real, To the joys of time and sense? Will it more, indeed, avail us Faith and reason to perplexâ Or, with wise Sardanapalus, Eat, and drink, and woo the Sex? What though, ever bending o'er us, Glooms a black and starless skyâ Let a jolly rouse restore us, Draining flask and flagon dry; Raise the catch, and roar the chorus, Fast and fierce while goblets flyâ Long the Night that lies before usâ Let us live until we die! Wine is physic meet for sadness, Impish Care from song must flit, Mirth is next of kin to gladnessâ Will the world outweigh a fit Of the fine celestial madness, Worth all wisdom and all witâ Which can make a common creature, Careless thousands might pass by, Dull of soulâand e'en in feature Irksome to a classic eyeâ Sovereign Empress of all nature, From the centre to the sky! Love is good, and so is Liquorâ Better still, methinks, the Weed! Soothing longer, kindled quicker, Trustier Fere in time of need. Lo, the wreath volute and taper, From its ashes spiral-curled, Born in fire, and lost in vapor, Floats, an emblem of the World. Spectral thus and evanescent All the splendor which thou seest; What is mightiest in the present, On the morrow may be leastâ Like yon pale imperial Crescent Waning in the stormy East. If the counter-charm of sorrows Lurks profound in Power or Fame, Let us live laborious morrowsâ Let us build a lofty Name! Kiss a long good-bye to Pleasure, Follow Fortune far and fastâ Eyes agape for rule or treasure, Nets in troubled waters castâ Harvest moonshine beyond measureâ But the end must come at last. If the morn of life has found us Happy in its milder raysâ If the fiery noon-tide crowned us With the glory of its blazeâ Darker shadows gather round us, In the evening of our days. Can the stoutest heart be cheery On a march to end like this? Yet a little, worn and weary, Every comrade thou shalt miss, On the pathway, stern and dreary, Leading to the vast Abyss. Past each sun-lit slope and meadowâ Under dead autumnal skies, In the Land of Dream and Shadow Deeper yet the journey lies. Still to seek the El Dorado That shall never meet our eyes. Fewer flowers are worth the gleaning, Drearier grows the Blasted Heathâ On we go, with listless meaning, Feebler footstep, fainter breathâ On a broken staff y-leaning, Slowly plodding on to death. Weary wayfarers from dawning, Calmly might we close our eyes, Could ye tell us that a Morning On our slumber shall arise! Hush the murmur unavailing, Breathed from too perturbed a breastâ Like a wayward infant's wailing, When it needs must go to rest. Would mere living on restore thee Hopes, that once were ever nigh? Think of those who died before thee, Think of those who yet shall die. Some there are thou canst remember, That might whisper words of powerâ In the silence of thy chamber, At the thoughtful midnight hour. Souls sublimed from sense and hating, Even in this terrene degreeâ Onceâhow noblyâanimating Dust and ashes! Can it be Thou in some far world art waiting, Thou that once wast all to me? In the depth of grief is lurking Truth divineâand man might draw Strength and comfort from the working Of the ever-constant Law. Standing on eternal mountains, Lifted from the plane of strifeâ Bathed in the o'erflowing fountains Of the Universal Lifeâ Hast thou not, in pure elation Born of Nature grand and free, Felt the glow of inspiration Shedding glimpses, e'en to thee, Of the glory of Creation, And the Joy that yet shall be? And the troubled heart is firmerâ And the sighing lips are dumbâ At the deep, prophetic murmur Of the Wondrous Age to come. Hear, with solemn, hushed emotion, Where, in distant thunder, beat Waves of the advancing Ocean Soon to lave our very feet. Through these early mists of morningâ Thrilling from the Unseen Shore, Voices of august forewarning Mingle with its endless roar; And a mighty Day is dawning, Such as never shone before! Lo, the long-unopened Portal On its threshold trembling stands! Through the ancient Shadow Curtal, Yet dividing these our Lands, They that once, like us, were mortal, Reach their dear remembered hands. Hopes undreamed shall those inherit, That are faithful to the endâ Death with Life, and Clay with Spirit, Shall converse, as friend with friend. Souls that erst, forlorn and lowly. Sat in darkness and dismay, Shall admire their melancholyâ Seeing every doubt decay In the Light, serene and holy, Of the Everlasting Day. Lo, the dream Earth's children cherish, In forgetting what they are! But, meanwhile, we faint and perish For the Fount that lies afar. God hath spoken, Christ hath risen, Saints have dwelt and died belowâ Yet the World is still a Prison, Full of wrong, and full of woe! On the 18th of June, 1846, a tribe of Arabs, pursued by the French, under Colonel Pelissier, took refuge in the intricate caverns of Ouled-Riah. Unable to compel a surrender, the savage commander resolved to burn or stifle them. For many hours, an immense fire, constantly fed with fresh combustibles, roared within the entrance. As it was permitted to subside, the French soldiery, at the hazard of their lives, dashed into the furnace, and drew forth the charred and contorted bodies of nine hundred victimsâmen, women and children.
